columns.text: The objective of this task is to determine which offer is better for the shareholders of the target company, as well as the exchange ratio that makes the two offers equal for the shareholders.

First, let's see the best option for shareholders of firm $T$,

On one hand, we have that they can obtain the amount of $\$19$ per share, this option will give them a profit of $\$19-\$16=\$3$ per share.

On the other hand, if the target firm is merged by share acquisitions, the shareholders will have half of the shares, for the offer that the bidder firm made, but, now the shareholders have their shares on the merger firm $(BT)$, where the new price per share is $\$44.36$. 

In simple terms, they must give two shares of $\$16$ for one of $\$44.36$:

The price of two $T$-shares is $2\times\$16=\$32$, so shareholders can increase the value of their share investment by $\$44.36-\$32=\$12.36$.

So shareholders will increase their share investment for times compared with the cash they can receive in the first option. From this perspective, shareholders of firm $T$ must prefer the share acquisition option!

Now we know the benefits for the stakeholders of choosing the share acquisition, let's find the **exchange ratio** in the share acquisition that can bring the same **price per share** resulting in the cash acquisition.

First, let us recall that for the **cash acquisition offer**, the cost of the firm $T$ is given by the **offered price per share** times **the number of shares**:

$$
\begin{equation}
\text{Cost }_T=1,200\times\$19=\$22,800
\end{equation}
$$

Notice that the task is reduced to just equate the left side of the equation $(1)$ with equation $(2)$ and then solve for **Exchange ratio**: $$ \begin{align*} \text{Cost }_T(\text{cash offer})&=\text{Cost }_T(\text{shares offer})\\[10pt] \$22,800 &=1,200\times\text{Exchange ratio}\times\$44.3559\\[10pt] \text{Exchange ratio}&=\frac{\$22,800}{1,200\times\$44.3559}\\[10pt] &=\boxed{0.4284} \end{align*} $$ ***So at the exchange ratio of $\bold{0.4284}$ per share, the shareholders of the firm $\bold{T}$ will be indifferent between the two offers***.

***Let's summarize our work!***

The **exchange ratio** is the share valuation that the share acquisition offer brings to the target firm, so we find the possible **exchange ratio** that brings the same cost of the target firm to the bidder firm!
